deadlineTip: ASAP — you’ll need proof you asked for repairs before filing.

title: File the LTB application
summary: Start an application for tenant rights/maintenance (commonly T2/T6).
actions: Complete LTB forms (T2: Tenant Rights; T6: Maintenance).
Attach evidence and your detailed timeline.

forms.name: LTB T2 — Application about Tenant Rights
LTB T6 — Tenant Application about Maintenance

deadlineTip: Some remedies are time-sensitive — file promptly.

title: Serve and prepare for the hearing
summary: Proper service and a clean evidence package matter.
actions: Serve as required; keep proof of service.
Organize exhibits, paginate, and prepare a short fact summary.

steps.title: Write down what happened and when
steps.summary: Map events, protected grounds, and adverse impacts.
actions: List dates, people involved, and witnesses.
Identify protected grounds (e.g., disability, family status).
steps.deadlineTip: HRTO has limitation periods — do not wait.

steps.title: Start your HRTO application
steps.summary: File Form 1 and Schedule A with facts and remedies sought.
actions: Complete the core application and attach Schedule A.
Describe remedies (monetary and non-monetary).
steps.deadlineTip: File before the deadline; extensions are discretionary.

steps.title: Determine if Small Claims is appropriate
steps.summary: Small Claims Court handles claims up to $35,000.
actions: Confirm your claim is $35,000 or less.
Ensure the defendant is in Ontario or the debt arose in Ontario.
Check if you have documentation of the debt.
steps.deadlineTip: You have 2 years from when the debt became due to file.

steps.title: File Form 7A - Plaintiff's Claim
steps.summary: Start your case by filing a plaintiff's claim.
actions: Complete Form 7A with details of your claim.
Include all supporting documents and evidence.
Pay the filing fee (varies by claim amount).
File at the Small Claims Court office.
steps.deadlineTip: File within limitation period (usually 2 years).

steps.title: Serve the defendant
steps.summary: The defendant must receive proper notice of your claim.
actions: Serve the defendant personally or by alternative method.
Keep proof of service.
File proof of service with the court.
steps.deadlineTip: Serve within 6 months of issuing the claim.

steps.title: Await defendant's response or attend settlement conference
steps.summary: The defendant has 20 days to respond, then a settlement conference is scheduled.
actions: Wait for defendant's defence (Form 9A) if filed.
Attend mandatory settlement conference.
Bring all documents and be prepared to negotiate.
steps.deadlineTip: Settlement conference usually within 90 days of defence.

steps.title: Understand your charges
steps.summary: Review the charges and your legal options.
actions: Read your appearance notice or promise to appear carefully.
Note your first court date.
Consider contacting duty counsel or a lawyer.
Review the Criminal Code sections you're charged under.
Understand potential penalties (fines, probation, jail).
steps.deadlineTip: Do not miss your first appearance date.

steps.title: Seek legal representation
steps.summary: Get legal advice before entering a plea.
actions: Apply for Legal Aid if you qualify financially.
Speak with duty counsel at courthouse (free).
Consider hiring a criminal defence lawyer.
Understand the difference between guilty plea, not guilty, and diversion options.
steps.deadlineTip: Get legal advice before your first appearance if possible.

steps.title: Attend first appearance
steps.summary: Appear in court on your scheduled date.
actions: Arrive early (at least 30 minutes) and dress appropriately.
Bring photo ID and court documents.
Check in with court staff.
Speak with duty counsel if you don't have a lawyer.
Enter your plea or request an adjournment to get legal advice.
Get future court dates in writing.
steps.deadlineTip: Failure to appear can result in a warrant for your arrest.

steps.title: Disclosure and Crown meeting
steps.summary: Review evidence and discuss with Crown prosecutor.
actions: Request disclosure (police reports, witness statements, evidence).
Review all disclosure with your lawyer.
Schedule Crown pre-trial meeting through your lawyer.
Discuss potential plea deals or trial options.
steps.deadlineTip: Review disclosure carefully - it contains the case against you.

steps.title: Trial or resolution
steps.summary: Proceed to trial or accept a resolution.
actions: If pleading guilty: understand sentencing range and consequences.
If going to trial: prepare with lawyer, gather defence evidence.
Consider diversion programs if eligible (mental health court, drug treatment).
Attend all scheduled court dates.
steps.deadlineTip: Missing court dates can result in additional charges.

steps.title: Document the incident immediately
steps.summary: Create a detailed record while memory is fresh.
actions: Write down date, time, location of incident.
Record officer names and badge numbers if visible.
List all witnesses with contact information.
Take photos of injuries, property damage, or scene.
Keep all related documents (tickets, medical records).
steps.deadlineTip: Document everything ASAP while details are fresh.

steps.title: Determine the right complaint body
steps.summary: File with correct agency based on nature of complaint.
actions: SIU: Serious injury, death, or sexual assault by police.
OIPRD: Police conduct, policy complaints, service complaints.
Police Service: Can also file directly with the police service.
Note: OIPRD can refer matters to SIU if appropriate.
steps.deadlineTip: SIU incidents should be reported immediately.

steps.title: File your complaint
steps.summary: Submit complaint through appropriate channel.
actions: OIPRD: File online at oiprd.on.ca or mail written complaint.
Include all evidence: photos, videos, witness statements.
Provide detailed chronological account of events.
Include impact statement (how incident affected you).
Keep copies of everything you submit.
steps.deadlineTip: Must file within 1 year of incident (some exceptions apply).

steps.title: Participate in investigation
steps.summary: Cooperate with investigators and provide additional information.
actions: Respond promptly to investigator requests.
Provide any additional evidence or witnesses.
Keep notes of all communication with investigators.
You can have a lawyer or support person present during interviews.
steps.deadlineTip: Respond to requests within deadlines given by investigators.

steps.title: Review decision and appeal if needed
steps.summary: Understand the outcome and your appeal rights.
actions: Review the decision letter carefully.
If dissatisfied, you can request review by OIPRD Director.
Appeal to Divisional Court within 30 days if necessary.
Consider consulting a lawyer about appeal options.
steps.deadlineTip: Appeal deadline is 30 days from decision.

steps.title: Understand CAS involvement
steps.summary: Know your rights and CAS's authority.
actions: CAS can investigate concerns about child safety.
You must allow CAS to see your child during investigation.
You have right to know why CAS is involved.
CAS can remove child only if immediate danger (then must go to court within 5 days).
Document all interactions with CAS workers.
steps.deadlineTip: Cooperate with investigation but get legal advice immediately.

steps.title: Get legal representation IMMEDIATELY
steps.summary: Child protection cases require a lawyer.
actions: Apply for Legal Aid Ontario - available regardless of income for CAS cases.
Contact a family lawyer with child protection experience.
Ask court for adjournment if needed to get lawyer.
Legal Aid: 1-800-668-8258 or apply online at legalaid.on.ca.
steps.deadlineTip: Do NOT go to court without a lawyer in CAS cases.

steps.title: Court process - temporary care hearing
steps.summary: First court date within 5 days if child apprehended.
actions: Attend court (failure to attend means case proceeds without you).
Court decides: child returns home, stays in care, or interim arrangements.
Judge may order conditions (counseling, no contact with certain people).
Follow all court orders exactly.
Future court dates will be scheduled.
steps.deadlineTip: NEVER miss a court date in a CAS case.

steps.title: Work on CAS concerns and plan of care
steps.summary: Demonstrate changes to address safety concerns.
actions: Complete all required programs (parenting, addiction treatment, counseling).
Attend all scheduled access visits with your child.
Document all efforts and progress.
Work with your lawyer to present evidence of positive changes.
Keep housing stable and safe.
Build support network (family, community resources).
steps.deadlineTip: Progress takes time - consistent effort is key.

steps.title: Trial or settlement
steps.summary: Final determination of child's placement.
actions: Possible outcomes: child returned, supervision order, society wardship (temporary), crown wardship (permanent).
Present all evidence of changes through your lawyer.
Call witnesses who support your case.
CAS must prove child is in need of protection.
Settlement conferences may resolve case without trial.
steps.deadlineTip: Trials must occur within specific timelines (varies by age of child).

steps.title: Determine if you can appeal to the Supreme Court
steps.summary: Most cases require leave to appeal.
actions: Review if your case involves a constitutional question or significant legal issue.
Obtain the lower court decision and reasons.
Consult with an appellate lawyer - SCC cases are complex.
steps.deadlineTip: Application must be filed within 60 days of final judgment.

steps.title: File Application for Leave to Appeal
steps.summary: Apply for permission to bring your appeal to the SCC.
actions: Complete the Application Record Form.
Include memorandum of argument (max 40 pages).
Pay required filing fees.
Serve all parties.
steps.deadlineTip: Strict 60-day deadline from final judgment.

steps.title: Gather employment records and evidence
steps.summary: Collect all documentation related to your employment and termination.
actions: Get employment contract, offer letter, job description.
Collect all pay stubs, T4s, ROE (Record of Employment).
Save all emails, texts, memos related to termination.
Get performance reviews and any disciplinary records.
List witnesses who can support your case.
Document timeline of events leading to dismissal.
steps.deadlineTip: Act quickly - ESA claims must be filed within 2 years.

steps.title: Determine type of claim and calculate damages
steps.summary: Identify what you're claiming and calculate what you're owed.
actions: Employment Standards Act claim (unpaid wages, vacation, termination pay).
Wrongful dismissal (common law - inadequate notice).
Constructive dismissal (forced to quit).
Calculate: termination pay, severance, vacation pay, notice period.
Rule of thumb: 1 month notice per year of service (varies by factors).
steps.deadlineTip: Consult lawyer for accurate damage calculation.

steps.title: Consult employment lawyer
steps.summary: Get legal advice before proceeding.
actions: Most employment lawyers offer free initial consultation.
Ask about contingency fee arrangements (no win, no fee).
Bring all employment documents to consultation.
Discuss settlement prospects vs. litigation.
Lawyer can send demand letter to employer.
steps.deadlineTip: Legal advice crucial for maximizing your claim.

steps.title: File your claim or application
steps.summary: Submit claim with appropriate body.
actions: ESA claims under $25,000: File with Ministry of Labour online.
Wrongful dismissal under $35,000: Small Claims Court.
Wrongful dismissal over $35,000: Superior Court.
Union grievances: File through your union.
Include all supporting documents and evidence.
steps.deadlineTip: File within limitation periods - usually 2 years.

steps.title: Participate in mediation or hearing
steps.summary: Attend settlement discussions or formal hearing.
actions: Most cases go through mediation first.
Be prepared to negotiate - most cases settle.
If no settlement, prepare for formal hearing.
Present evidence and witness testimony.
Employer must prove just cause if claiming it.
steps.deadlineTip: Settlement often faster and less stressful than trial.

steps.title: Make your refugee claim
steps.summary: File your claim for refugee protection in Canada.
actions: Make claim at port of entry or inland at IRCC office.
Receive acknowledgement and referral to IRB.
Get your Basis of Claim (BOC) form kit.
Apply for work permit while claim is pending.
Register for healthcare coverage if eligible.
steps.deadlineTip: Make claim as soon as possible after arriving in Canada.

steps.title: Get legal representation immediately
steps.summary: Immigration law is complex - you need a lawyer.
actions: Contact Legal Aid Ontario for free refugee legal services.
Find immigration lawyer through Law Society referral.
Many lawyers offer initial free consultation.
Do NOT proceed without legal advice.
Lawyer will help prepare your case and BOC form.
steps.deadlineTip: Get lawyer before BOC deadline (15 days after referral to IRB).

steps.title: Submit Basis of Claim (BOC) form
steps.summary: Your written story explaining why you need protection.
actions: Complete BOC form in detail - this is your written testimony.
Explain why you left your country and fear returning.
Include specific dates, names, locations, events.
Identify protected grounds (race, religion, nationality, political opinion, social group).
Your lawyer will help draft this critical document.
steps.deadlineTip: CRITICAL: Must submit within 15 days of referral to IRB.

steps.title: Gather evidence and documents
steps.summary: Collect all supporting documents for your claim.
actions: Identity documents (passport, birth certificate, national ID).
Evidence of persecution (threats, police reports, hospital records).
Country condition documents (human rights reports, news articles).
Witness statements from people who know your situation.
Expert reports if applicable (psychological, country expert).
Photos, videos, social media evidence.
steps.deadlineTip: Submit all documents at least 10-45 days before hearing.

steps.title: Prepare for your IRB hearing
steps.summary: Practice your testimony and get ready for your hearing day.
actions: Meet with lawyer multiple times to prepare.
Practice answering questions about your story.
Review your BOC form thoroughly - you'll be asked about it.
Prepare for cross-examination by government lawyer.
Arrange interpreter through IRB (free service).
Know what documents you'll need to bring.
steps.deadlineTip: Hearing typically 12-24 months after claim filed.

steps.title: Attend your refugee hearing
steps.summary: Present your case to the IRB member.
actions: Arrive early with lawyer and all original documents.
Testify honestly and completely about your experiences.
Answer all questions - don't guess if you don't know.
IRB member may ask for clarification or additional evidence.
Decision may be given verbally at end of hearing or in writing later.
If accepted: Apply for permanent residence.
If refused: Discuss appeal options with lawyer immediately.
steps.deadlineTip: If refused, you have 15 days to appeal to RAD.

steps.title: Understand your appeal rights
steps.summary: Determine if you can appeal the immigration decision.
actions: Review the refusal or removal order carefully.
Check if you have right to appeal to Immigration Appeal Division (IAD).
Permanent residents and some family class sponsors can appeal.
Refused refugee claimants appeal to Refugee Appeal Division (RAD), not IAD.
Note strict deadlines for filing appeal.
steps.deadlineTip: Appeal deadlines vary - usually 15-30 days from decision.

steps.title: File notice of appeal
steps.summary: Submit your appeal to the Immigration Appeal Division.
actions: Complete IAD notice of appeal form.
Include copy of decision being appealed.
Pay filing fee (or apply for fee waiver).
Serve copy on CBSA or IRCC.
File within deadline or application to extend time.
steps.deadlineTip: File within deadline - late appeals may be dismissed.

steps.title: Prepare appeal submissions
steps.summary: Build your case for why decision should be overturned.
actions: Review reasons for refusal - address each concern.
Gather new evidence that wasn't available at first decision.
Get letters of support from family, employers, community.
For H&C appeals: Show hardship if family separated.
Prepare detailed written submissions with lawyer.
Submit disclosure package before hearing.
steps.deadlineTip: Submit evidence package 20-60 days before hearing.

steps.title: Attend IAD hearing
steps.summary: Present your appeal to the Immigration Appeal Division.
actions: Attend hearing with lawyer and all witnesses.
Present evidence showing decision was wrong in law.
Or, argue humanitarian and compassionate grounds.
Call witnesses to testify.
Government may oppose your appeal.
IAD can allow appeal, dismiss, or issue removal order with conditions.
steps.deadlineTip: Hearing typically 12-36 months after filing appeal.
